results.title: Penicillin: the magic bullet
results.creator_credit: Arcimedia, Claire Jager and Gordon Glenn
results.brief_description: In 1945 the Nobel Prize for medicine was awarded to three men - Alexander Fleming, Ernst Chain, and the Australian, Howard Florey - as the inventors of penicillin, the “magic bullet” of medicine. This doumentary tells the true story behind the discovery of penicillin, the wonder drug of the twentieth century, which would change the face of modern civilisation by providing a cure for medical scourges such as pneumonia, meningitis, rheumatic fever, septicaemia and venereal diseases. Using dramatic re-enactments, “Penicillin : the magic bullet” charts the work of the Howard Florey’s team (including that of the overlooked Norman Heatley) as they struggled towards this medical breakthrough. Narrated by Martin Jacobs.

results.title: Penguin island: Australia's little penguins
results.creator_credit: BandG Communications, Gordon Badham and Patrick Gillespie
results.brief_description: Hosted by Peter Hoskings, this is a tourist orientated film that never the less provides a wealth of facts and figures about the fairy penguins, and background information about Phillip Island. Excellent cinematography reveals much about the scenary and wild life of the island including koalas, kangaroos and wallabies, wombats, seals, wild flowers and birds.

results.title: Penguin Island
results.brief_description: A film record of the various types of animal life found by the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition (1948-1950) during their stay on Macquarie Island. Shows many species of seals, penguins and birds, including the Great Wandering Albatross. Recordings of sounds made by penguins are used in the introduction to the film.

results.title: Penance: Sacrament of peace
results.creator_credit: Franciscan Communications Centre and Bruce Bailer
results.brief_description: A dramatisation illustrating the universal story of sin, repentance, reconciliation and peace. Ray Hendricks, driving home from a cocktail party, accidentally strikes a little girl. He tries to cover up his guilt and remorse by attempting to convince himself and others that because he was cleared by the police, he is not guilty of anything. He finally risks the confrontation and visits the little girl. She gives him sympathy because he looks hurt, and her naive assumption of this basic goodness brings him peace.

results.title: Pen point percussion: an introduction to hand-drawn sound of Norman McLaren
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Norman McLaren and Tom Daly
results.brief_description: The first part of this film presents an explanation of the principles and production of synthetic sound in motion pictures, showing Norman McLaren’s experimentation with hand-drawn sounds on film. The film is designed as an introduction to McLaren’s animated productions. An oscilloscope records what various sounds look like - the trembling strings of a guitar, the low tones of a tuba, the crow of a rooster and the human speaking voice. Norman McLaren then demonstrates on a moviola the sounds that emit from a soundtrack on which he has drawn dots, lines and triangles and we note how these sounds are synchronised with the artist’s hand-drawn animations. (6 mins.) Written by Don Peter. Photographed by Lorne C. Batchelor. Music by Louis Applebaum. (Award: Venice). The second part presents Norman McLaren’s experimental film ‘Dots’ made in 1948 which demonstrates his innovative technique and illustrates what can be created by drawing directly onto the picture and soundtrack area of film stock. (2 mins.) Other films in the collection related to this technique include ‘The Eye hears the ear sees’, ‘Synchronomy’ and ‘Loops’. (Awards: Toronto, Salerno, Rome)

results.title: Pembrokeshire, my county
results.creator_credit: British Information Services, Andrew Rice and Ronald Stark
results.brief_description: A film on the Welsh country of Pembrokeshire,, through the seasons, showing the scenic beauty of the countryside, buildings of interest, and something of agriculture and social life of the country. Highlights of the film include shots of abundant wild life of the region, pleasures of sailing at Milford and unique scenes in the Cistercian monastery at Caldey Island.

results.title: Pelle the conqueror = Pelle Erobreren
results.creator_credit: Per Holst Filmproduktion, Danish Film Institute, Svensk Filmindustri, Per Holst and Bille August
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Martin Andrew Nexos “Pelle the Conqueror” is the epic adventure of two Swedish refugees - eleven year-old Pelle and his elderly, widowed father Lasse (played by Oscar nominee Max Von Sydow). They sail to Denmark in search of a better existence but their dreams quickly fade when they realise that life is not any easier in their new country. Faced with extreme cruelty and poverty, Pelle develops an inner strength that helps him to endure the hardships. Armed with the determination to succeed, he sets out alone to conquer the world. Also stars Pelle Hvengaard, Erik Paaske, Bjorn Granath. Awarded Best Film - Cannes 1988; Best Foreign Film - Oscar 1988 Original subtitled version.
